attributes.magic: ELF 32-bit LSB executable, Intel 80386, version 1 (SYSV), statically linked, Go BuildID=NfdMI_WBy9HUsSRHUemJ/zMqiHU7xymt3p4qIFwuz/_7eN8rIoWR1JTSj6cNi5/II1EYyQFtjtQrhM8IuRq, stripped

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects the presence of a number of Windows API functionality often seen within embedded executables. When this signature alerts on an executable, it is not an indication of malicious behavior. However, if seen firing in other file types, deeper investigation may be warranted.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_category: Malware Command and Control Activity Detected
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET MALWARE Golang/Kaos/YamaBot CnC Activity"; flow:established,to_server; http.user_agent; content:"TW96aWxsYS81LjAgKFdpbmRvd3MgTlQgMTAuMDsgV2luNjQ7IHg2NCkgQXBwbGVXZWJLaXQvNTM3LjM2IChLSFRNTCwgbGlrZSBHZWNrbykgQ2hyb21lLzYwLjAuMzExMi4xMTMgU2FmYXJpLzUzNy4zNg=="; reference:url,blogs.jpcert.or.jp/ja/2022/06/yamabot.html; reference:md5,612538328e0c4f3e445fb58ef811336a; reference:md5,cf1a90e458966bcba8286d46d6ab052c; classtype:command-and-control; sid:2037241; rev:3; metadata:affected_product Windows_XP_Vista_7_8_10_Server_32_64_Bit, attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2021_03_18, deployment Perimeter, malware_family Lazarus, signature_severity Major, updated_at 2022_07_01;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET MALWARE Golang/Kaos/YamaBot CnC Activity M2 (POST)
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET MALWARE Golang/Kaos/YamaBot CnC Activity M2 (POST)"; flow:established,to_server; http.method; content:"POST"; http.uri; content:".php"; endswith; http.user_agent; content:"TW96"; startswith; fast_pattern; pcre:"/^(?:[A-Za-z0-9+/]{4})*(?:[A-Za-z0-9+/]{2}==|[A-Za-z0-9+/]{3}=|[A-Za-z0-9+/]{4})$/"; http.header_names; content:!"Referer"; reference:md5,cf1a90e458966bcba8286d46d6ab052c; reference:md5,612538328e0c4f3e445fb58ef811336a; reference:md5,76125115415a80c4ec4c9b1a440f6054; reference:url,blogs.jpcert.or.jp/ja/2022/06/yamabot.html; classtype:trojan-activity; sid:2037252; rev:1; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2022_07_01, deployment Perimeter, malware_family Lazarus, signature_severity Major, updated_at 2022_07_01;)

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: The sample is a Go-based backdoor, identified by developer paths as 'kaos' (e.g., `_/C_~/administrator/Downloads/kaos/engine/Egg.go`). It demonstrates clear malicious behavior by collecting system information (OS name, IP, user), generating a unique ID (`utilities.GenerateUniqueID`), and exfiltrating data, including files, via HTTP POST requests (`utilities.HttpPostWithFile`). The binary is capable of executing arbitrary shell commands via `/bin/sh` (`os/exec`) and uses cryptography (`crypto/aes`, `encoding/base64`) likely to obfuscate its C2 communications.
